awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Transforming the Evaluation of Teaching: A Study of Institutional Change to Advance STEM Undergraduate Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The economic prosperity of the United States relies on progress in science, the advancement of national health initiatives, and overall national prosperity in an increasingly technical economy. This prosperity relies on a talented workforce with the ability to nimbly address new challenges and develop innovative technologies. Colleges and universities can best prepare this future workforce by adopting evidence-based, student-centered teaching approaches. This project will support and study the adoption of new approaches to teaching evaluation that encourage the use of teaching practices known to support the excellence in learning needed to address national needs. Universities have long relied on student surveys as the primary means of evaluating instruction, despite their significant limitations. By introducing a scholarly framework for the evaluation of teaching, this project will help faculty members create a shared vision of effective teaching in their discipline, identify appropriate forms of evidence of effective teaching, and apply the resulting framework for such means as mentoring, annual evaluations, promotion and tenure. Given that four-year public colleges and universities accounted for 40% of the 17 million undergraduates enrolled in US universities in 2014 (National Center of Education Statistics), the work in this project to study the development and implementation of new approaches to evaluating teaching will provide models for change at hundreds of similar institutions that enroll millions of students.

In this project, the University of Kansas, the University of Colorado at Boulder and the University of Massachusetts Amherst will approach change in ways best suited to their campus culture. Each, though, will implement an evaluation framework that is based on two decades of scholarship on scholarly teaching and its evaluation. The framework draws on multiple sources of evidence, including students, peers, instructors, and that speaks to multiple dimensions of teaching and learning. The work on each campus will center on the development and use of a teaching evaluation rubric that provides a richer, more complete view of teaching practice, and the evidence that speaks to it. Leaders and faculty members at each campus will also share their experiences with colleagues at the other universities, creating faculty learning communities that will provide further means for improving teaching. The researchers will study the process of transformation within and across the three campuses, focusing on what approaches work most effectively under what circumstances. Informed by theories of organizational change and organizational learning, case studies of each campus will illuminate the strategies and processes that lead to adoption of new approaches to teaching evaluation. The cross-case analysis will provide greater insight into the ways in which these strategies and processes interact with institutional cultures and contexts. The research findings will also serve to uncover aspects of institutional change for teaching evaluation that may be adaptable by many institutional types. Project findings will be disseminated through knowledge exchange meetings, professional and scholarly conferences, meetings of senior institutional leaders, reports, and articles in order to provide models of effective teaching evaluation to higher education institutions throughout the country.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the TEval Project has been to improve approaches to teaching evaluation—and thus, to strengthen teaching and educational experiences in the undergraduate context. Our premise is that teaching involves an array of activities and thoughtful practices, and that teaching evaluation practices should take into account and address that array of work. In doing so, teaching evaluation brings to the foreground the various dimensions of teaching-related responsibilities and helps instructors think more reflectively about their teaching, often in interaction with other thoughtful and dedicated colleagues. In this way, efforts to improve approaches to teaching evaluation help instructors improve their teaching practice, and thus, improve the learning of the full range of diverse learners in higher education.

The specific focus of the project has been to promote and study the adoption and integration of new approaches to teaching evaluation. Three institutions have served as incubators to develop and implement such strategies and approaches. Cross-case comparisons have illuminated how these strategies and processes interact with different institutional cultures. The long-term outcomes of the project include: changes in practice, tools and resources, greater understanding of institutional change, and national dialogue around transforming teaching evaluation.

Changes in Practice. Changing teaching evaluation practices is not easy. However, by the conclusion of our project, each campus has seen meaningful shifts in the ways in which teaching is documented and evaluated. They have moved toward a reward system that aligns with and encourages faculty use of effective, inclusive, and scholarly educational practices, and one that is more equitable and resistant to bias than traditional methods of evaluation. Across the three institutions, approximately 80 academic units (ranging from STEM fields to Arts, Humanities, Social Sciences and Business) have successfully integrated adaptations of the TEval approach into formal evaluation processes (e.g., promotion/tenure, annual evaluation), often in combination with formative approaches emphasizing improvement (e.g., mentoring, peer review triads). These department-level changes have been accompanied by shifts in university-level processes around teaching evaluation (e.g., revised student evaluation tools, changing expectations for promotion and tenure processes, and revised union contracts). The framework has also been adapted and used in departments at many other universities. 

Tools and Resources. In partnership with the early adopter departments on each campus, the TEval project has also resulted in the development of numerous tools and resources to support more equitable and effective teaching evaluation systems. These include rubrics that externalize expectations for a broad range of teaching activities at varying levels of performance; protocols to guide peer review of courses; guides for self-reflection; department templates for annual review; mapping tools to align evidence and artifacts with different teaching dimensions; sample evaluation portfolios; supplements and glossaries on inclusive teaching elements; repositories of department adaptations and examples; and department-level case studies highlighting change processes. Useful resources document these tools, including a website (Teval.net), department guides and toolkits, and a forthcoming book, Transforming Higher Education through Teaching Evaluation: Strategies for Departmental and Institutional Change Initiatives (Harvard Education Press).  

Improved Understanding of Institutional Change. This work has also advanced understanding of institutional change processes, particularly with respect to the high-stakes, fraught context of teaching evaluation. Key lessons learned emphasize that, while institutional contexts must be considered, common approaches and tools for quality teaching evaluation can be used across a wide array of institutions.  Furthermore, change leaders must attend to barriers, seek allies across the institution, and build toward sustainability and institutional embeddedness.  Collaborations and partnerships are essential, both within and across institutions, to motivate participation, provide models & tools for practice, and foster adaptation to challenges that arise.  Finally, these efforts are accelerated through national dialogue and discourse that promote and value quality teaching evaluation as a core practice of academic institutions.

The National Dialogue. The TEval project has also helped to shape and propel a national dialogue around the topic of transforming teaching evaluation. The TEVal project has partnered with other communities, including the Association of American Universities, the Accelerating Systemic Change Network, the Bay View Alliance, APLU’s Network of STEM Education Centers, the National Academies Roundtable on Systemic Change in Undergraduate STEM Education, and the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, to collectively foster a national conversation around the transformation of teaching evaluation. A workshop in 2019 and a National Dialogue in early January 2021 advanced collective discussion. In October of 2021, TEval hosted an online, three-day public Knowledge Exchange and Summit for more than 220 people from 90 institutions, followed by a June 2023 Summit on Teaching Evaluation. These events connected people who were already interested in transforming teaching evaluation, brought greater attention to the topic, and fostered community- and capacity-building for teaching evaluation transformation. The most recent Summit advanced even broader dialogue on building national infrastructure (e.g. a national center or organization) to support the further development and broad use of scholarly approaches to teaching evaluation.
